awd_titl_txt: Synthesis Driven by Release of Ring Strain
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Cha of the Department of Chemistry at Wayne State University is investigating an efficient preparation of several molecular building blocks that have utility in organic and medicinal chemistry.  The research project begins with readily available cyclopropanols: three-membered ring compounds that are tensioned like a spring and said to have ring strain. Reactions that open the three-membered rings are driven to completion by releasing this ring strain. The Cha laboratory developed a significantly improved preparation of these cyclopropanols.   They are developing new reactions of cyclopropanols to build more complex molecules that may have useful medicinal properties.  This project is an excellent training ground for young scientists, from undergraduate researchers to post-doctoral fellows, to learn about chemistry. 

The specific goals for the project include the design of new chemical reactions that facilitate concise and environmentally benign syntheses of important structural motifs or natural products. Emphasis is placed on high efficiency and convergence by use of segment coupling strategies, in which two large fragments are linked at a late stage in the synthesis.  Concise total syntheses of suberosenone and alkaloid 261C are underway.  These syntheses highlight the preparative power of the newly developed synthetic methods.  Suberosenone and alkaloid 261C are both scarce natural products, and chemical syntheses are necessary to evaluate their biological activity.  Through participation in this project, students and postdocs are trained in organic methods development, organometallic chemistry and natural product synthesis.  They are well prepared for careers in chemistry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division has supported the research program by Professor Jin K. Cha in the Department of Chemistry at Wayne State University. His research aims to design new methods for joining attractively functionalized molecular fragments for efficient syntheses of valuable structural motifs or structurally complex natural products. The key approach features a segment coupling of combining separately prepared, large molecules toward the end of a synthesis.  This strategy helps streamline the overall synthetic sequence compared to linear syntheses for rapid access to molecular complexity.

 

Specifically, Professor Cha and coworkers have focused on the segment coupling reactions of readily available, yet judiciously functionalized cyclopropanols or in situ generated titanacyclopropanes to afford unique and efficient routes to frequently encountered structural motifs. These versatile reactions are made possible by the convenient synthesis of cyclopropanols by the titanium-mediated cyclopropanation. A powerful variant of the latter reaction was developed by the Cha group, following Professor Kulinkovich’s seminal discovery by use of inexpensive and sustainable titanium isopropoxide.

 

The research has advanced fundamentally new ring opening reactions of functionalized cyclopropanols for efficient carbon–carbon forming reactions, such as alkylation, alkenylation, alkynylation, and acylation of cyclopropanols.  Methods developed are hoped to have broader impacts on the ways in which complex molecules are synthesized.  These advances have the potential of enabling new opportunities in other scientific disciplines, including materials sciences, biology, agrichemicals and medicinal chemistry. The research program encompasses organic synthesis, organometallics, and physical organic chemistry to provide a well-rounded education of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. Professor Cha has a track record of training, mentoring, and educating coworkers.  

 


Last Modified: 06/14/2022
Modified by: Charles H Winter
